mark.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to write or draw on something, so that someone will notice what you have written
mark.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I’ve marked the pages you need to look at.
All school uniform should be clearly marked with the child’s name.
Any student who is more than 20 minutes late for class will be marked absent.
When you’re done, put your sheet in the envelope marked with your name.
Peter marked his name on the first page.
mark.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to make a mark on something in a way that spoils its appearance or damages it, or to become spoiled in this way
mark.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Take off your shoes so you don’t mark the floor.
The disease had marked her face for life.
The table marks easily, so please be careful.
mark.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Mrs Lawson was presented with a gold watch to mark the occasion.
Carter’s 90th birthday will be marked with a large party at the Savoy Hotel.
mark.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: A simple wooden cross marked her grave.
He had marked the route on the map in red.
She placed a bookmark between the pages to mark her place.
Troop positions were marked with colored pins.
mark.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if a particular year, month, or week marks an important event, the event happened on that date during a previous year
mark.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: This week marks the 250th anniversary of the birth of Joseph Priestley.
mark.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to be a sign of an important change or an important stage in the development of something
mark.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Her latest novel marks a turning point in her development as a writer.
The move seemed to mark a major change in government policy.
These elections mark the end of an era.
mark.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: if something is marked by a particular quality or feature, it is a typical or important part of that thing
mark.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: The villages of East Anglia are marked by beautiful churches with fine towers.
mark.translation[0].definitions[6].note_: Mark is usually passive in this meaning
mark.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to read a piece of written work and put a number or letter on it to show how good it is
mark.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: I’ve got a pile of exam papers to mark.
mark.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to stay close to a player of the opposite team during a game
mark.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a spot or dirty area on something that spoils its appearance
mark.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I can’t get these marks out of my T-shirt.
His feet left dirty marks all over the floor.
The skid marks (=marks left by a car’s tyres) were over 30 feet long.
mark.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a cut, hole, or other small sign of damage
mark.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: a burn mark on the kitchen table
There were scratch marks all over the victim’s body.
mark.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a small area of darker or lighter colour on a plain surface such as a person’s skin or an animal’s fur
mark.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The kitten is mainly white with black marks on her back.
mark.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a shape or sign that is written or printed
mark.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: What do those strange marks at the top mean?
Make a mark at the bottom of the page.
mark.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a particular level, number, amount etc
mark.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: The temperature is not expected to reach the 20 degree mark in the next few days.
In 1976 unemployment in Britain passed the one million mark.
mark.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: a letter or number given by a teacher to show how good a student’s work is
mark.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: Her marks have been a lot lower this term.
The highest mark was a B+.
mark.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: the standard unit of money used in Germany before the Euro
mark.translation[1].definitions[7].defin: a sign in the form of a cross, used by someone who is not able to write their name
mark.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: Her lipstick had made a mark on his collar.
The glass had left a mark on the table.
The product removes greasy marks from clothes.
I can’t get this dirty mark to come out.
His scratch marks have faded, but the memories never will.
There were black marks all over the floor.
What’s that dirty mark on your coat?
It’s good for getting greasy marks off carpet.
The track was pretty soft and there were tyre marks.
After the accident, two sets of skid marks were found.
There appeared to be scorch marks on the ceiling.
Most women get stretch marks when they have a baby.
Her arms were covered in itchy bite marks.
The chairs had made scratch marks on the floor.
mark.translation[1].note_box[1].sections: a dirty mark
a dirty area on something that spoils its appearance
The bark of the tree had made black marks on her trousers.
spot
a small mark on something
a grease spot on my shirt
stain
a mark that is difficult to remove, especially one made by a dark liquid
a wine stain on the tablecloth
blood stains
smudge
a mark that is made when something touches against a surface
There was a smudge of lipstick on his cheek.
He had a smudge of chalk on his jacket.
smear
a mark that is made by a small amount of something spread across a surface
The table had a smear of paint on the top.
fingerprint
a mark on the surface of something that is made by someone’s fingers
The glass was covered with greasy fingerprints.
a mark on your skin
blemish
a mark on your skin that spoils its appearance
John grew a beard to hide the blemishes on his chin.
mole
a small dark, sometimes raised, mark on your skin
Some moles may become cancerous.
Helena found a mole on her arm which had definitely not been there before.
freckles
small light brown marks on your skin, especially on your face but also on your arms, shoulders etc
She had a light sprinkling of freckles across her nose.
birthmark
a permanent mark on your skin that you have had since you were born
There was a small birthmark on her left cheek.
bruise
a purple or brown mark on your skin that you get because you have fallen or been hit
Her legs were covered in cuts and bruises.
scar
a permanent mark on your skin, caused by a cut or by something that burns you
The injury left a small scar on his forehead.
pimple/zit
a small raised red mark or lump on your skin, which usually appears when a child is between 12 and 18 years old
When I was a teenager I had terrible spots.
The boy had a few pimples under his chin.
wart
a small hard raised mark on your skin caused by a virus
His face was covered in hairy warts.
blister
a small area of skin that is swollen and full of liquid because it has been rubbed or burned
There was a blister on his arm where the boiling milk had splashed him.
rash
an area of small red spots on your skin, caused by an illness or an allergy
I can’t eat strawberries - they give me a rash.
mark.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: There is usually a fee to be paid, generally around the £100 mark plus VAT.
mark.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to put a sign on something
mark.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: You must mark all hazardous goods with international danger symbols.
